input:
1. A 28-year-old male presented with a three-year history of progressive gait instability and frequent falls. He reported difficulty speaking clearly and noted increased stiffness in his legs, making walking increasingly effortful. On examination, he exhibited spasticity in the lower limbs, hyperreflexia, and a broad-based ataxic gait. Mild dysarthria and nystagmus were also observed during the neurological assessment. Family history revealed that his father had similar symptoms starting in his early thirties. MRI of the brain showed mild cerebellar atrophy without other structural abnormalities. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Spastic Ataxia 1 with expanded CAG repeats in the ATXN1 gene. Supportive physical therapy and symptomatic treatment for spasticity were initiated to improve mobility and quality of life.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I want to explain how I've been feeling lately and see if the doctor can help me figure out what's going on since I've been having all these odd symptoms for quite a while now. I might sound a little overwhelmed or unsure because I don't really understand everything myself. I should keep it simple and honest about what I've been experiencing.

ANSWER: Well, I guess I've just been having a lot of problems with walking and my speech. I fall a lot more now and everything just feels really hard to do, like my legs are stiff or something. It’s been going on for a few years, but it’s gotten worse recently and I’m pretty confused about why it’s happening.

input: 1. A 28-year-old male presented with a three-year history of progressive gait instability and frequent falls. He reported difficulty speaking clearly and noted increased stiffness in his legs, making walking increasingly effortful. On examination, he exhibited spasticity in the lower limbs, hyperreflexia, and a broad-based ataxic gait. Mild dysarthria and nystagmus were also observed during the neurological assessment. Family history revealed that his father had similar symptoms starting in his early thirties. MRI of the brain showed mild cerebellar atrophy without other structural abnormalities. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Spastic Ataxia 1 with expanded CAG repeats in the ATXN1 gene. Supportive physical therapy and symptomatic treatment for spasticity were initiated to improve mobility and quality of life.Can you tell me more about how your walking, speech, and daily functioning have changed over time, and if there are any other symptoms or concerns you've noticed?
output: Well, I guess my walking has gotten really harder, and I fall more often now. My speech sometimes gets all mixed up, and I feel like my legs are stiff all the time. There are days I feel more tired or kind of out of it, and I’ve noticed my eyes don’t move quite right sometimes. It’s kind of hard to tell what’s really changing, but everything feels like it’s getting more complicated.

output: Well, I think I’ve been worse at walking and maybe a little more off balance, and my speech is sometimes really hard to understand. I haven’t noticed anything really different with my vision or anything else, but I guess I feel kind of down about how things are going.

output: Well, um, I guess I sometimes see things a little funny, like spots or things moving.
